Perhaps "A cloud-based static analyzer service for Java, C/C++, C#, JavaScript, Ruby, or Python that is free for open source projects"?

comment_data.body: `clang-tidy` is a "linter" tool, but `cpplint` is a checker. You'd think they would be described using the same terminology, whether as linter or checker.

comment_data.body: Since the rest of README is talking about Tox/Toxcore , it's just a bit confusing as to why this section is in the README, how is it Tox-related? Is this a list of tools that use toxcore? Is this a list of tools that toxcore provides when built? So on. Perhaps the confusion is made worse when you don't know what SAST is. So just adding a sentence like this should make things abundantly clear, otherwise it's a bit cryptic if you are not in the know.

comment_data.body:
I'm pointing out the inconsistency that they are the same type of a tool, yet we use two "synonyms" for it (for the type of a tool they are) in the same list: one is being called "linter" and another "checker", when sticking with just one terminology would have been more consistent. So just make both use either "linter" or "checker".

Eh, maybe I'm just being too pedantic. You already fixed the more egregious things, like missing articles, inconsistent capitalization and one tool having oddly inconsistent description sentence format in comparison to others. This one, while somewhat inconsistent, is arguably fine, so I will approve the PR without it being addressed.

performed_via_github_app.description:
Codecov provides highly integrated tools to group, merge, archive and compare coverage reports. Whether your team is comparing changes in a pull request or reviewing a single commit, Codecov will improve the code review workflow and quality.

## Code coverage done right.Â®

1. Upload coverage reports from your CI builds.
2. Codecov merges all builds and languages into one beautiful coherent report.
3. Get commit statuses, pull request comments and coverage overlay via our browser extension.

When Codecov merges your uploads it keeps track of the CI provider (inc. build details) and user specified context, e.g. `#unittest` ~ `#smoketest` or `#oldcode` ~ `#newcode`. You can track the `#unittest` coverage independently of other groups. [Learn more here](
http://docs.codecov.io/docs/flags)

Through **Codecov's Browser Extension** reports overlay directly in GitHub UI to assist in code review in [Chrome](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/codecov/gedikamndpbemklijjkncpnolildpbgo) or Firefox (https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/codecov/)

*Highly detailed* **pull request comments** and *customizable* **commit statuses** will improve your team's workflow and code coverage incrementally.

**File backed configuration** all through the `codecov.yml`. 

## FAQ
- Do you **merge multiple uploads** to the same commit? **Yes**
- Do you **support multiple languages** in the same project? **Yes**
- Can you **group coverage reports** by project and/or test type? **Yes**
- How does **pricing** work? Only paid users can view reports and post statuses/comments.
performed_via_github_app.name: Codecov

comment_regular_data.body: @iphydf I see that you just copy-pasted the descriptions from GitHub repositories and websites, but it's just too inconsistent when combined into a list, they require some more cleanup instead of being used as is.

commit.message:
docs: Add static analysis tool list to README.

Helping the tools gain visibility and showing others that we're doing
our best to use many static analysis tools.
